planets.name: Mercury
details: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and is closest to the Sun. It is named after the Roman messenger god due to its swift orbit around the Sun, completing a full revolution in just 88 Earth days. Its rocky surface is heavily cratered, resembling Earth's Moon, and has no plate tectonics to reshape its terrain. Scientists believe Mercury's core makes up about 85% of its volume, a much larger proportion than other terrestrial planets.

It is the first planet from the Sun and has an extremely thin atmosphere, known as an exosphere, composed mainly of oxygen, sodium, and hydrogen. With no significant atmosphere to retain heat, Mercury experiences drastic temperature fluctuations, ranging from a scorching 430°C during the day to freezing lows of -180°C at night.

Mercury has a slow rotation, taking 59 Earth days to complete a single spin on its axis. Interestingly, a day-night cycle on Mercury (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 176 Earth days due to its 3:2 resonance between rotation and orbit. This makes it one of the most unique rotational systems in our Solar System.
fun_facts: Mercury is the fastest planet in the Solar System, zipping around the Sun in just 88 Earth days.
Mercury's surface is covered in large cliffs called 'lobate scarps,' which formed as the planet's core cooled and contracted.
The planet has water ice in permanently shadowed craters at its poles, despite its proximity to the Sun.

planets.name: Venus
details: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and is often called Earth's twin due to its similar size and composition. However, its thick atmosphere, extreme surface pressure, and searing temperatures make it vastly different. Venus is covered by a dense layer of clouds composed of sulfuric acid, which trap heat in a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in the Solar System.

It is the brightest natural object in Earth's night sky after the Moon, earning it nicknames like the 'Morning Star' and 'Evening Star.' Its surface is a volcanic landscape, with more volcanoes than any other planet in the Solar System. Scientists believe some of these volcanoes may still be active. The surface pressure on Venus is about 92 times that of Earth's at sea level, equivalent to being 900 meters underwater.

Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets, a phenomenon known as retrograde rotation. This means the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east. A single day on Venus lasts longer than its year, taking 243 Earth days to rotate on its axis while orbiting the Sun in just 225 Earth days.
fun_facts: Venus is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty.
It is the only planet in the Solar System that rotates clockwise on its axis.
Venus has no magnetic field, possibly due to its slow rotation.

planets.name: Earth
details: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only planet known to harbor life. It is often referred to as the 'Blue Planet' because of its vast oceans, which cover about 71% of its surface. Earth's atmosphere is primarily composed of nitrogen (78%) and oxygen (21%), with trace amounts of other gases, making it suitable for life as we know it.

It is the largest of the terrestrial planets in terms of diameter, mass, and density. Earth’s magnetic field, generated by its molten iron core, protects it from harmful solar radiation, and its axial tilt of 23.5° gives rise to seasons. The planet's surface is dynamic, with tectonic activity and erosion constantly reshaping the landforms.

Earth completes an orbit around the Sun in approximately 365.25 days, with its rotation on its axis taking about 24 hours. The Moon, Earth’s only natural satellite, stabilizes its tilt and affects tides, playing a crucial role in the planet's climate and life cycles.
fun_facts: Earth is the only planet not named after a Greek or Roman deity.
70% of Earth’s surface is covered in water, yet less than 3% is fresh water.
Earth’s core is as hot as the surface of the Sun, reaching temperatures up to 6000°C.

planets.name: Mars
details: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and is often called the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance caused by iron oxide (rust) on its surface. It is the second smallest planet in the Solar System and has a thin atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide.

Mars has the tallest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, which stands about 21 kilometers high, and the largest canyon, Valles Marineris, stretching over 4,000 kilometers. Evidence suggests that liquid water may have flowed on Mars in the past, and scientists are actively exploring its potential to support life.

Mars takes about 687 Earth days to complete one orbit around the Sun. Its rotation period is similar to Earth's, lasting just over 24 hours. The planet has two small, irregularly shaped moons, Phobos and Deimos, thought to be captured asteroids.
fun_facts: Mars has seasons, polar ice caps, and weather patterns similar to Earth.
The gravity on Mars is about 38% of Earth’s, so you’d weigh less than half as much there.
A Martian day, called a 'sol,' is 24 hours and 39 minutes long.

planets.name: Jupiter
details: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest planet in the Solar System, with a mass more than 300 times that of Earth. It is a gas giant primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, with no solid surface. Jupiter’s fast rotation creates distinct bands of clouds and the famous Great Red Spot, a storm larger than Earth that has been raging for centuries.

It is the first of the outer planets and plays a key role in protecting the inner Solar System from asteroid impacts due to its immense gravitational pull. Jupiter has at least 79 moons, the four largest of which—Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto—are known as the Galilean moons.

Jupiter completes an orbit around the Sun in about 12 Earth years, but it rotates very quickly, with a day lasting just under 10 hours. The planet also has faint rings, although they are much less prominent than those of Saturn.
fun_facts: Jupiter’s magnetic field is 14 times stronger than Earth’s.
Ganymede, one of Jupiter’s moons, is the largest moon in the Solar System, even bigger than Mercury.
Jupiter radiates more heat than it receives from the Sun.

planets.name: Saturn
details: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second largest in the Solar System. It is best known for its stunning ring system, which is made up of ice particles, rocky debris, and dust. Saturn is a gas giant composed primarily of hydrogen and helium, with a small, dense core.

It is one of the least dense planets, with an average density lower than water. Saturn is also famous for its strong winds, which can reach speeds of up to 1,800 kilometers per hour near its equator. Like Jupiter, Saturn emits more energy than it receives from the Sun due to the slow compression of its core.

Saturn takes about 29.5 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun. It has at least 83 moons, including Titan, the second-largest moon in the Solar System, which has a dense atmosphere and lakes of liquid methane and ethane.
fun_facts: Saturn’s rings are so large that they could span the distance between Earth and the Moon.
Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, is the only moon in the Solar System with a dense atmosphere.
If you could place Saturn in a bathtub (a very large one), it would float due to its low density.

planets.name: Uranus
details: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and the third-largest by diameter. It is unique in the Solar System for rotating on its side, with an axial tilt of 98 degrees, likely caused by a massive collision in its early history. This tilt gives Uranus extreme seasonal variations, with each pole experiencing 42 years of continuous sunlight followed by 42 years of darkness.

It is an ice giant, composed mainly of water, ammonia, and methane ices, along with hydrogen and helium. The methane in its atmosphere absorbs red light, giving Uranus its characteristic blue-green color. Uranus has a faint ring system and at least 27 known moons, named after characters from the works of Shakespeare and Alexander Pope.

Uranus takes 84 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun. Despite its distance, it has strong winds, reaching speeds of up to 900 kilometers per hour. Its cold temperatures make it the coldest planet in the Solar System, with a minimum temperature of -224°C.
fun_facts: Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope, by William Herschel in 1781.
Its magnetic field is tilted at a bizarre angle compared to its rotation axis.
A day on Uranus lasts about 17 hours and 14 minutes.

planets.name: Neptune
details: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It is the smallest of the ice giants but has the strongest winds, with speeds exceeding 2,000 kilometers per hour. Its deep blue color is due to the presence of methane in its atmosphere, which absorbs red light.

It was the first planet predicted to exist based on mathematical calculations rather than direct observation. Neptune’s atmosphere is composed mainly of hydrogen, helium, and methane, and it has a system of faint rings composed of dust and ice particles.

Neptune takes about 165 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun, making it one of the slowest-moving planets. It has 14 known moons, the largest of which is Triton, a geologically active moon with geysers that spew liquid nitrogen.
fun_facts: Neptune is the only planet in the Solar System not visible to the naked eye.
Triton, its largest moon, orbits in the opposite direction to Neptune’s rotation, suggesting it was captured from the Kuiper Belt.
Neptune has storms known as 'Dark Spots,' similar to Jupiter's Great Red Spot.
